chapter-2_key2: True and False, using capital T and F, with the rest of the word in lowercase
chapter-2_key14:
False

False
False

==, !=, <, >, <=, and >=.
chapter-2_key15: == is the equal to operator that compares two values and evaluates to a Boolean, while = is the assignment operator that stores a value in a variable.
chapter-2_key16: A condition is an expression used in a flow control statement that evaluates to a Boolean value.
chapter-2_key17: The three blocks are everything inside the if statement and the lines print('bacon') and print('ham').
chapter-2_key19:
if spam == 1:
print('Hello')
elif spam == 2:
print('Howdy')
else:
print('Greetings!')
Press CTRL-C to stop a program stuck in an infinite loop.
chapter-2_key20: The break statement will move the execution outside and just after a loop. The continue statement will move the execution to the start of the loop.
chapter-2_key21: They all do the same thing. The range(10) call ranges from 0 up to (but not including) 10, range(0, 10) explicitly tells the loop to start at 0, and range(0, 10, 1) explicitly tells the loop to increase the variable by 1 on each iteration.
chapter-2_key24:
i = 1
while i <= 10:
print(i)
i = i + 1
This function can be called with spam.bacon().
